intro: Carex spicata f. pseudoguestphalica, commonly known as the false guestphalica sedge, is a variant of the common spikerush. It is a perennial plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family, characterized by its grass-like appearance and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in wet or moist environments such as marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. It has narrow, linear leaves and produces small, greenish-brown flowers in dense spikes. This form is distinguished by subtle morphological differences from the typical Carex spicata, including variations in leaf structure and inflorescence architecture.
